author: Chris Hughes
title: Shocking pictures of bodies of 74 migrants washed ashore on Libyan beach highlight refugee crisis in Mediterranean
text:
News Shocking pictures of bodies of 74 migrants washed ashore on Libyan beach highlight refugee crisis in Mediterranean The bodies of the migrants, mostly adult men, were lined up on the beach in body bags by Red Crescent aid agency workers Share   
The bodies of 74 migrants have washed up on a Libyan beach, highlighting the horror of the worsening refugee crisis in the Mediterranean. 
Police and officials were last night trying to identify those killed, all of whom are believed to have drowned whilst fleeing the North African country. 
All of the corpses landed near the western Libyan city of Zawiya, according to the Red Crescent aid agency, and were all adults, mostly men with three women among them. 
Spokesman for Red Crescent Mohamed al-Misrati said the bodies had been recovered on Monday and that the migrants appeared to have died during the past two days. 
It is believed they were mostly from African sub-Saharan countries. 
The Red Crescent published pictures of the bodies laid out in white and black body bags along the beach. 
Libya is the main departure point for migrants hoping to flee war, poverty and oppression to reach Europe by sea. Red Crescent workers carry one of the bodies off the beach in a bodybag (Photo: Libyan Red Crescent) The horrific scale of the tragedy is apparent when all the bodies are lined up together (Photo: Libyan Red Crescent) 
Mostly they try to cross in flimsy inflatable craft loaded with small amounts of fuel which are intended to get them only as far as European rescue vessels stationed in international waters. 
Several British warships have taken part in massive rescue operations in which thousands of migrants have been pulled out of the water just out of sight of the coast of Libya. Read More Yes, it IS a Muslim ban: Why Donald Trump's travel ban is as bad as it sounds 
Royal Navy warships involved in rescue operations stay out of sight of the Libyan coast for fear of being hit by al-Qaeda or Islamic State missiles. 
British Royal Navy ships like HMS Bulwark have in the past then taken the migrants on to drop-off points in Sicily, where they are processed, given food and shelter and can have asylum claims scrutinised. A torn rubber dinghy was found nearby (Photo: Libyan Red Crescent) More than 270 people migrating are believed to have drowned in the Mediterranean in the first weeks of 2017 (Photo: Libyan Red Crescent) 
People smugglers - many of whom have deals with Islamic State terrorists - - can make hundreds of thousnds of pounds from each boatload. 
The badly-made migrant boats have to travel 800 miles to Libya and often capsize so an international armada of rescue ships is on daily patrol to stop passengers drowning. 
The ruthless trafficking gangs are being hunted down by western special forces and Italian police - with rescue boats carrying detailed descriptions and photographs of the ring-leaders. Read More SAS in battle to rid Mosul of ISIS as armoured vehicles packed with Iraqi soldiers head to city 
The Daily Mirror has seen British Royal Marines arresting several suspected people smugglers aboard a sinking boat as they were brought onto HMS Bulwark. 
The men were then handed over to a Sicilian special investigations unit and it is believed they were trying to pretend to be migrants and set up a base in Sicily. Red Crescent workers walk back down the beach to collect more corpses (Photo: Libyan Red Crescent) The body bags are labelled before being moved off the beach (Photo: Libyan Red Crescent) (Photo: Libyan Red Crescent) The beach became a graveyard for tragic migrants (Photo: Libyan Red Crescent) 
Most depart from the stretch of Libyan coast between Tripoli and the Tunisian border to the west. 
The bodies of those who drown are frequently found washed up on Libyan shores- victims of Mediterranean storms or vicious tides. 
Last year a record 181,000 migrants crossed between Libya and Italy. 
More than 4,500 are known to have died. 
Having largely closed off sea crossings between Turkey and Greece last year, the European Union is searching for ways to stem the flow of migrants from Libya. 
This month European leaders offered Libya money and other assistance to try to reduce the numbers departing across the Mediterranean. 
Aid groups criticised the move, saying such plans exposed migrants to further risks and abuses within Libya. Like us on Facebook
